topic.title: Thoughts on "Cubbit"?
topic.body:
4 terabytes of distributed cloud storage, where each user supports a physical storage node, instead of using a data center. I like distribution and evolving beyond centralized networks, but I'm not really sure cloud storage is the best use case. What they're offering is 512 GB of storage for about $340 USD, when 1 TB external drives go for like $50, and work offline.

Decentralized sites have a very strong use case because they cannot be taken down. But Cubbit is just storing files. I don't doubt that it is more secure than something like Dropbox or Google Drive. But is cloud storage really all that cost effective for the marginal use you get out of it? If you buy one of these storage units, it doesn't house your files on it, just fragments of other people's files, so when the internet goes down, you're still fucked.

You can "expand" your storage to 4 TB, but in order to do so you have to go buy a 4 TB USB hard drive and plug it into the Cubbit unit. So you're basically paying a few hundred dollars to turn a USB hard drive into cloud storage, losing offline capability, and the ability to install software to it among other things.

Link to their campaign with more info: https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/cubbit/cubbit-reinventing-the-cloud?

topic.title: Spaces of critique
topic.body:
Cultural critique exists in spaces that have not yet been consumed by the object of critique: virtual reality and the internet were once feverishly talked about by cyber-cultural theorists even through most of the 90s, as these were spaces not yet taken over by state or global interests, and so critiques of power structures could be safely be made from within them.
Obviously this is not the case, as the internet is an apparatus of the state and of state corporations; critiques made on the internet are now highly scrutinized by the corporate media, and in many countries they are actually policed by law enforcement. Virtual reality is subsumed by marketing--we're treated to watching a cartoon of Mark Zuckerberg in a simulated, disaster-struck Puerto Rico. 
But like any medium, it is content-agnostic, and while critiques can be printed in books, those books exist in separate space, often times obeying separate laws of publication, or rather refusing to obey laws of publication at all. For the medium of the internet to serve as a medium of critique, there must be separate spaces that are absolutely independent of the state/corporate internet. I remember last year we had fun mapping ZeroNet but pinpointing user locations on the globe: the map of ZeroNet essentially fits "within" the map of the internet proper; it is a space within the medium. I believe maps are a very useful tool for visualizing critical spaces: the internet as a concept has been so thoroughly warped by external power structures that it can no longer be "mapped" as a medium, but rather as spaces with different functions and forms.
In this way, ZeroNet is not the final solution to centralized internet, but rather a hint of what is to come later: non-interacting networks created as-needed, functioning as spaces for operations which cannot be permitted on the Clearnet.

1552558114_16NS3rBdW9zpLmLSQoD8nLTtNVsRF.body:
Morphic resonance. "Form" is a field like gravity or magnetism that determines the shapes objects take as they form, on an atomic level. For all our advances in chemistry and crystallography, we still cannot mathematically predict how molecules of as few as six atoms will form, let alone the forms of massive organic molecules. And the speed at which atoms arrange themselves into their proper molecular forms is far too fast to be trial-and-error through rotations.
Morphic fields persist throughout time and without regard to distance, as they are non-physical. Once an object begins to form a certain way, it makes future objects of the same nature more likely to form in that way, just as rain trickling down a slope forms niches that water is more likely to follow the paths of. Chemists who synthesize new chemicals often have trouble in making them crystallize, but later iterations form much more quickly: the sugar turanose was considered a liquid for decades, but after it first crystallized in the 1920s, it began crystallizing all over the world. Xylitol, a sugar alcohol used as a gum sweetener, was first made in 1891 and was a liquid until 1942 a form with a melting point of 61 degrees centigrade formed; several years later, another form with a melting point of 91 degrees centigrade formed, and now the liquid form cannot be made anymore. Ritonavir, an AIDS drug made by Abbott Laboratories, was first made in 1996; after 18 months on the market, an unknown polymorph of the drug began to form, and within a few days, only the new polymorph would synthesize. The new form was only half as soluble as the old and after spending a massive amount of time and money trying to make the old form synthesize again, they gave up and produced the new form, recommending double the dosage (they were able to create the original polymorph, but not reliably, as it would now frequently form in a mixture with the new polymorph).
If it's true that morphic fields exert influence regardless of distance, then it's possible that on another planet, the a similar kind of molecule began forming a certain way on such a large scale that it changed the way these molecules now form on our planet.

1554477808_17AMQVbBa12XB3xFWKDnP2dCEx92T.body:
The two most common scenarios argued over, I believe, are 1. Monitoring by private services for the sake of ad revenue, and 2. Monitoring by state agencies. State agencies are of course the greater threat, as you can delete your Facebook and Google accounts any time, and isolate yourself from their practices, while government agencies are typically more "compulsory" to put it lightly.
RE: surveillance by private companies, basically it makes the Internet a worse place. Websites have become monstrously inaccessible without overtaxing your browser/hardware because the amount of crap they have to load--namely ads and the various tracking/monitoring scripts used to sell them. A free-as-in-freedom decentralized net will never evolve so long as this ad dependency goes unchecked, and opting to use open source or non-tracking premium software reduces this stagnation.
RE: government surveillance, this one is a bit more obvious, but it is worth talking about due to the extent to which it leverages private companies. Intensive monitoring in junction with a convoluted and illegitimate legal code allows the state to incarcerate citizens it views as enemies based on non-offenses (see: anti-terrorism laws being used to incarcerate peaceful activists world wide in the last decade).
There is also a junction between the two which we haven't really seen come onto the scene yet, but should be wary of: private websites with political agendas controlling access to resources. This mainly refers to the spoken-of possibility of Google or Facebook becoming the de-facto portal for things like hiring employees, credit approval, etc. and red-flagging job-seekers whose personal beliefs expressed in "private" messages do not align with the personal beliefs of the site team.
Though I would not advocate for the banning of this or that or anything in the private sector, only the involuntary tracking by the state of course; I would instead advocate and support new services that are privacy-minded instead of the vertical stacks that exist now.

> [anonymouslogin](#comment_236_17AMQVbBa12XB3xFWKDnP2dCEx92TaiY7X): I wish it was though......

John C. Calhoun, an American politician in the 19th century, wrote about leadership through consensus quite a bit. He recognized that there will always be people who benefit from government at the expense of others: those who give more than they receive from it, and those who receive more than they give. He proposed a form of government modeled after the Roman and Polish monarchies, in which there were representatives that all had veto power over one another--plebeians can veto the laws of patricians and vice versa. Of course, nobody wants to play fair like that. The supreme court has been the real aim of political parties for decades because having 5 justices gives you absolute power over the legal system. Vetos for me but not for thee. A nation without laws or leaders is a simple extension of Calhoun's principle of fairness--no one group having total authority over another, where something's strength is derived from its value, not from its power or from violence.

> [anonymouslogin](#comment_244_17AMQVbBa12XB3xFWKDnP2dCEx92TaiY7X): Where there is universal mutual respect, I think this utopian view of anarchy might work.
By mutual respect, I assume you mean respect for property. This isn't just a requirement for practical anarchy, it is a requirement for really any system in which people have any degree of freedom. And I think it is clear that the government fails in this regard: businesses and employees are taxed excessively, and states seem to have some inevitable tendency to invade one another which obviously does not respect the property of those being invaded. 
Think of the wars of religion in Europe, prior to the separation of church and state: denominations fighting for control of the government because it gives them the authority to wipe out their opponents; the same thing happens now, between the classes, between races, the sexes etc. 
What I think you fail to see here is that the lack of respect between groups in a statist society exists because these groups can use the state to control one another, rather than negotiate and cooperate. Mutual respect comes from the mutual understanding that negotiating is better than fighting because violence just depletes resources, including human resources, and creates an untenable, unstable society: no one will bother to accumulate resources or create things if they can have it all taken away by force in an instant. And the idea that mutual respect just never existed before the state is ridiculous. Like if you lived in a small town, you'd know--people don't just gouge each other on prices because you quickly gain a reputation for being greedy and unfair and you're ostracized, your kids are ostracized, it's just generally unpleasant for all parties involved. Mutual respect is an inevitable, emergent property of successful communities, and communities with mutual respect for property rights are exponentially more prosperous and productive than those which do not have this understand of respect, and they eventually collapse while societies built on the respect of property rights prosper and spread.
So mutual respect for one another is not exactly hard to come by in a free society, but in a statist society, where it is possible for one group to gain control over the property of another group through force (the working class using taxes to take wealth from the upper class; the military industrial complex taxing the general population for billions of dollars to pay for weapons), you don't need respect for property rights to get what you want anymore, so it vanishes.

> [anonymouslogin](#comment_256_17AMQVbBa12XB3xFWKDnP2dCEx92TaiY7X): I agree that most public services should be pay for use. ... The key is to make sure the corporations and ruling elite pay the people enough to afford ALL of the services they require. The reality is so far away for any number of reasons, but mostly just greed. 

Sorry to double-post but my client was out of sync and I missed this comment.
>Most public services should be pay for use
Why most and not all? I'm sure you've heard of the "problem of the commons;" it is essentially a case for privatization. If you want something taken care of sustainably and efficiently, then let people express value in it. You want clean water, so instead of regulations, have companies that will ensure water quality: the company has an incentive to keep water clean because if they don't they have to pay out; a portion of the client payments can then be invested in sanitation infrastructure, R&D, etc., because these things will earn the insurance company more money in the long run.
Prices are information: how much people are willing to pay for what under what circumstances. They're offered by sellers but ultimately they are determined by customers, praxeology. The idea that you can "make sure" all the prices are right essentially means you can distribute all the resources just right. The information contained in prices signals what resources need to go where; the market behaves as a collective intelligence in this way. And people have studied the "planning problem" for a century at this point, at least. The fact of the matter is you cannot replicate, much less predict, this collective intelligence. So trying to set taxes and minimum wages and hours and vacation days and so on is ridiculous. Not only is it less efficient than letting people decide for themselves, but on what moral grounds can you interfere? It is immoral to deprive someone of their sovereignty, and you can't just do it sometimes and not others, it's not subjective. So if you actually believe it is a moral imperative to preserve sovereignty, then on what possible grounds can you violate it?
>GREED
I won't spend long on this one, because it is the most nonsensical. How do you draw a line between an amount of wealth that constitutes greed and an amount that does not? In order to even codify and enforce such an idea, you must have such a lust for power, to wish to appropriate the possessions of others, who would prefer to be left alone, that even the wealthiest among us cannot comprehend the greed for control and domination that smolders in the hearts of socialists and regulators.
And it's all so arbitrary anyway. Is it morally wrong for someone to be poor? If so, then are monks and ascetics "evil" for choosing to be poor? Obviously not--there is no real evil in wanting or not wanting something. What's evil is taking away that choice. Calling people greedy and suggesting that their actions should be legally controlled and dictated is far more dangerous than anyone running a business with voluntary employees, offering prices that people are free to accept or reject.

> [anonymouslogin](#comment_260_17AMQVbBa12XB3xFWKDnP2dCEx92TaiY7X): Industrialized nations don't account for the external costs of their products.
That is true, nations don't account for external costs, businesses and customers do. And I already gave a pretty fair example of how environmental costs are handled in a free society. People want clean air, people want clean water, people don't want mercury and coal dust dumped in their back yards, and if you privatize these costs with DROs, then suddenly you have people spending money on protecting the environment, and that money is invested in R&D and infrastructure to limit environmental damages; and the companies with the best R&D divisions sell the best technology to other firms and so on.
I don't know what you do for a living, I don't want to make any presuppositions, but I do think that people who don't work natural resource management have been painted an inaccurate picture of how procurement companies function. I manage forests and timber/fiber plantations, and here in the southeastern United States, 95% of forested land is privately owned, it is productive, well kept, and sustainably managed because people harvest the wood on it. You hire timber cruisers to assess the property, some trees are taken for lumber, others are left to regrow the forest. Meanwhile the government managed land out west is Hell--theirs is used more for grazing than forestry of course but compare the value of an acre of government land set aside for ranchers to graze cattle on to an acre of privately managed land, it's night and day.
>If the environmental cost of a gallon of gasoline were factored into the price, no one would be able to afford it.
The Duke study I found on social/environmental costs pegs the "adjusted" price per gallon $6.27 a gallon. If that were the case then people would probably switch to more fuel efficient vehicles; I don't think "no one would be able to afford it." And I get it--that's the point--raise prices so people will switch to cleaner habits. Like I said, I work in natural resource management, I am a conservationist, one who actually works to develop sustainable management plans and preserve forest ecosystems, not a politician or armchair environmentalist who calls for ineffective laws to be passed and then blame companies when things keep getting worse. But the cause is not gasoline being too cheap: the only reason demand drives gasoline prices so far down is because things like road usage are free, and when the government constructs new roads, it doesn't have to pay anyone for the environmental damages caused by road use, usually because it's on government owned land that they have no financial incentive to conserve.
Some articles on road privatization which reference multiple studies on the effects of toll roads:
https://www.wired.com/story/gas-tax-vmt-toll-road/
https://www.wired.com/story/virginia-i66-toll-road/
>In this way the most egregious offenders have the highest profit margins, and ethical companies can't compete.
This is another fabrication. For one, in a free society you would get more money for running a clean business because of funds from insurance companies, so you'd make more money by cooperating with them, so long as people are allowed to express interest in environmental quality. And it's not just reactive either, it's not just "Oh this mining company set up shop and dynamited a whole mountain, took the ores and skipped town just as the salmon started dying off." You'd have certification agencies which examine company plans, methods, supply chains etc., and can give the company a stamp of a aproval or not. Companies that are certified as sustainable get more customers on the wholesale market because A. it means they will be around longer and your supply point won't suddenly dry up five years down the road, and B. they conduct business in an ethical way, meaning there won't be any major scandals that link back to you, which would ruin your company's reputation when people find out you knowingly purchased supplies from an uncertified procurement company.
Again, not wanting to make presuppositions but I don't get the impression that you've worked in this kind of field before. I think it's great that you care about the environment--I do too, I spent the majority of my adult life working to maximize sustainable yields in the timber industry, something that takes a little bit more commitment than reading an article about social costs and casting a vote for a government program funded with someone else's money.
>Regulation is the best way to make the business playing field equal and protect the environment.
Reality thoroughly disproves that point. US business regulations push manufacturing into countries with less sustainable infrastructure and even less free economies in which the government faces no consequences for environmental damages. If you want people to pay for environmental costs, start with the government: the government is able to print money at will meaning environmental costs don't even exist to them. When the Canadian government set fishing limits on Newfoundland, the social restrictions that prevented over-fishing were superseded and the fishing industry there practically died off overnight.
If you want further reading, I would suggest any of Molyneux's books on practical anarchy--before he became a writer he was a software entrepreneur who developed greentech software to help companies manage environmental impacts, and programs to assist in maintaining workplace safety standards and the like (things that companies are in fact interested in). Additionally Anderson & Leal's "Free Market Environmentalism" is a comprehensive book on the subject.

> [atomiserxenolith](#comment_64_1CFQMjPvz8m5BHtMnGyE7tRktdQ69WwUSX): People look for one 'dear leader' who can take all the responsibility and do all the thinking for them ...
And it's not just that these leaders don't know how to run X. It's that NOBODY knows how to run X, when it's sufficiently complex. Nobody knows how to "run" the timber industry, it's a combination of so many disciplines and fields of study. So people tend to specialize and then collaborate with other experts as needed. So political leaders--I'm not saying Donald Trump is stupid, but the idea that you can "run" a country is ridiculous. But it's the Dunning-Kruger effect: if you don't know much about something, then you think it's more simple than it really is. The only people stepping up to the plate, with good intentions anyway, are the ones who really underestimate the task of political leadership. The ones who know exactly what they're doing are the ones doing it for power and wealth, because they know that the state exists to benefit a select few people, they don't have any illusions of it benefiting the masses, so they just want to be one of the few. Think of where these politicians would be without the state? Nobody would ever hear about them, and they certainly would not have the hundreds of millions of dollars that the Obamas and the Clintons etc. have.
>If some of the contributors here had to put their money where their mouth is, it wouldn't be long before they had very little currency left to do any damage with their shallow and irrelevant thinking.
I think this also highlights the impetus for "benevolent" big government. Helping people is really hard. I've tried to help friends go on a diet or quit smoking and THAT'S hard enough. It is so difficult to truly help people, that everyone would rather just pay taxes and vote for government programs and then feel like they've helped someone. Of course it doesn't work, you can't just throw resources at people to fix all of their problems--if someone is trying to go on a diet and keeps cheating then throwing money at them won't do anything, it'll probably make it worse. If someone has a drinking or smoking problem, then throwing tax dollars at them isn't going to do anything--making it illegal for healthcare providers to discriminate against people who are overweight or sedentary etc. is certainly not providing any incentive for them to get healthy. You can't help people with government programs, they do not work, and if anybody thinks so, then I can promise you they have not really and truly tried to help these people themselves because then they would know it is not that simple. And I'm not against charity--I think we need charity. But charity has to be managed, intensely, by some kind of organization, whether that is the church or non-compulsory union whatever. But we can't let the state manage this.

> [anonymouslogin](#comment_267_17AMQVbBa12XB3xFWKDnP2dCEx92TaiY7X): In a political environment requiring a "leader" like the body of a serpent needs a head
Projects need leaders, companies need leaders, any functioning organization needs some kind of hierarchy, I'm not arguing against that. But realistically how much can you organize under a single person or board of individuals, before the whole thing becomes too bloated or spread out and they lose control? In the business world this the difference between large companies and startups: small businesses driven by passionate individuals can outmaneuver large companies. When you run a "large" business, if you want to, say, upgrade your office computers, you have to buy thousands of computers, and which usually means bidding for a lot in an auction and then having people install them in all the workspaces and that's all peanuts compared to the task of building and maintaining an office intranet connecting all those machines. If you're a startup of like 15 people working remotely, your overhead is basically nothing compared to the large business. And of course if a small business succeeds it usually is incorporated into a parent company or it becomes a large company itself and the cycle continues. Businesses have an average lifespan of like 40 years. If you look at the 100 largest businesses of a hundred years almost all of them are gone now, it's one of the reasons this fear of monopolies in a free market is so ridiculous.

So the state can be thought of as a "large company" where the "leader" has less control over the direction of the business, except that the business has gotten so large and is in charge of so many different things that the leader has no control whatsoever. And that's where we get the "deep state", spin doctors, the unelected secretaries serving life terms influencing elected politicians in certain governmental structures like in the UK. The leader has so little control over the individual parts that they begin to function autonomously, but instead of becoming these efficient self-governing bodies, they become corrupt because they still act with the perceived authority of the leader. One problem we have in the US in particular is these divisions and agencies competing against one another directly: the department of the interior, the department of agriculture, the bureau of land management, forestry service, fish and wildlife service--these agencies don't get along, to say the least. One of the reasons New Zealand has a proportionately more efficient timber industry is because they have fewer government agencies competing against one another in land management.

Basically if you want the leadership of the state to actually function, you have to shrink the state down to a size where it does not become unraveled and corrupt. So let's say you get the government shrunk down to a size where it can be managed (at which point we probably don't need it). The problem with that is no matter how small you shrink the state, it will always grow bigger again. So long as it has the monopoly on violence, so long as it can redistribute wealth to give people what they want in the short-term, then people will always let it get bigger, they will WANT it to get bigger. It doesn't work--shrinking the government does not work--you have to gt rid of it.
